column1: Gatineau (; French: [ɡatino]) is a city in western Quebec
column2: Canada. It is the fourth largest city in the province after Montreal
column3: Quebec City
column4: and Laval. It is located on the northern bank of the Ottawa River
column5: immediately across from Ottawa
column7: together with which it forms Canada's National Capital Region. As of 2016

column1: The current city of Gatineau is centred on an area formerly called Hull
column2: the oldest European colonial settlement in the National Capital Region. This area was mostly not developed until after the American Revolutionary War
column3: when the Crown made land grants to Loyalists for resettlement in Upper Canada.

column1: Hull was founded on the north shore of the Ottawa River in 1800 by Philemon Wright at the portage around the Chaudière Falls just upstream (or west) from where the Gatineau and Rideau rivers flow into the Ottawa. Wright brought his family
column2: five other families
column3: and twenty-five labourers to establish an agricultural community. They considered the area a mosquito-infested wilderness. But soon after
column4: Wright and his family took advantage of the large lumber stands and became involved in the Ottawa River timber trade. The original settlement was called Wrightstown
column5: and was later renamed as Hull. In 2002
column7: it was part of a larger jurisdiction named the City of Gatineau.

column1: Gradually French Canadians also migrated to the township; their proportion of the population increased from 10% in 1850
column3: and 90% in 1920.The Gatineau River
column4: like the Ottawa River
column5: was a basic transportation resource for the draveurs
column6: timber rafters who transported logs via the rivers from lumber camps until they arrived downriver. (The Gatineau River flows south into the Ottawa River
column7: which flows east to the St. Lawrence River near Montreal.) The log-filled Ottawa River
column9: was featured on the back of the Canadian one-dollar bill; the paper money was replaced by a dollar coin (the "loonie") in 1987. The last of the dwindling activity of the draveurs on these rivers ended a few years later.

column2: as the terminus of the Rideau Canal. This was built under the command of Col. John By as part of fortifications and defences constructed after the War of 1812 against the United States. Originally named Bytown
column3: Ottawa was not designated as the Canadian capital until the mid-19th century
column4: after the original parliament in Montreal was torched by a rioting mob of Anglo-Canadians on 25 April 1849. Its greater distance from the Canada–US border also made the new parliament less vulnerable to foreign attack.

column1: Nothing remains of the original 1800 settlement of Hull. The downtown Vieux-Hull sector was destroyed by a terrible fire in 1900; it also burnt down the original pont des Chaudières (Chaudière Bridge). The bridge was rebuilt to join Ottawa to Hull at Victoria Island.

column2: during World War II
column3: Hull
column4: along with various other regions within Canada
column5: such as the Saguenay–Lac-Saint-Jean
column7: was the site of prisoner-of-war camps. Hull's prison was identified only by a number
column8: as were Canada's other war prisons. The prisoners of war (POWs) were organized by nationality and status: civilian or military status. In the Hull camp
column9: POWs were mostly Italian and German nationals detained by the government as potential threats to the nation during the war. As a result of the Conscription Crisis of 1944
column10: Canadians who had refused conscription were interned in the camp. The prisoners were required to perform hard labour
column11: which included farming and lumbering the land.During the 1970s and early 1980s

column1: As part of the 2000–06 municipal reorganization in Quebec
column2: the five municipalities that constituted the Communauté urbaine de l'Outaouais (Outaouais urban community) were merged on 1 January 2002 to constitute the new city of Gatineau. They were:

column1: Masson-AngersAlthough Hull was the oldest and most central of the merged cities
column2: the name Gatineau was chosen for the new city. The main reasons given were that Gatineau had more residents
column3: and this name was strongly associated with the area: it was the name of the former county
column4: the valley
column5: the hills
column6: the park and the main river within the new city limits.  Some argued that the French name of Gatineau was more appealing to the majority French-speaking residents.

column1: Since the former city of Hull represents a large area distinct from what was formerly known as Gatineau
column2: some people refer to "Vieux Hull". The name "Hull" was often informally used to refer to the entire urban area on the northern shore of the river facing Ottawa. In other areas of Quebec
column3: the National Capital Region was often referred to as "Ottawa-Hull".After the 2003 election
column4: the new Liberal government of Jean Charest passed Bill 9
column5: which created a process by which former municipalities could be reconstituted. Contrary to Charest's election promise of full de-amalgamation
column6: Bill 9 restored only selected powers to the de-merged cities (e.g.
column10: some cultural facilities). The bigger expenses (e.g.
column14: expansion programs) and the majority of the taxes remained in the hands of urban agglomerations. These are controlled by the central merged city because their larger populations give them greater voting weight. 10% of the eligible voters in each former municipality would have to sign a "register" in order to hold a referendum on de-amalgamation.

column2: Buckingham
column3: Hull and Masson-Angers all surpassed this threshold in seeking a referendum on de-merge. A simple majority of "yes" votes
column4: based on a turnout of at least 35%

column1: A number of federal and provincial government offices are located in Gatineau
column2: due to its proximity to the national capital
column3: and its status as the main town of the Outaouais region of Quebec.

column1: A policy of the federal government to distribute federal jobs on both sides of the Ottawa River led to the construction of several massive office towers to house federal civil servants in downtown Gatineau; the largest of these are Place du Portage and Terrasses de la Chaudière
column2: occupying part of the downtown core of the city. Some government agencies and ministries headquartered in Gatineau are the Public Works and Government Services Canada
column3: Aboriginal Affairs and Northern Development Canada
column4: Environment Canada
column5: Transportation Safety Board of Canada.The following federal government departments have their main offices in Gatineau:

column1: Aboriginal Affairs and Northern Development Canada
Environment Canada (includes offices of Parks Canada)
Public Works and Government Services CanadaThe following agencies have their main offices in Gatineau.
Transportation Safety Board of Canada (under Transport Canada)
Passport Canada (under Citizenship and Immigration Canada)

column2: the Canadian Patent Office and the Canadian Radio-television and Telecommunications Commission (under Innovation
column3: Science and Economic Development Canada)In addition to housing a significant portion of federal government offices
column4: the city is also an important regional centre for the Outaouais region. The city serves as the location for the Superior Court of the District of Gatineau
column5: which encompasses all neighboring municipalities. It also houses 2 of the region's major hospitals as well as numerous provincial colleges.

column1: Gatineau's economy relies on a few important sectors. A majority of jobs are accounted for between the federal government
column2: construction and service industries. There is however a large effort to modernize the economy in the region through recent initiatives in the entrepreneurial and innovation ecosystem. The Innovation Gatineau Institute is a regional innovation centre that boasts co-working space as well as startup incubation and acceleration programs to spur innovative business creation. Michael-Anthony Clement is currently the CEO of the Innovation Gatineau Institute.

column1: Two important tourist attractions located in Gatineau are the Canadian Museum of History and the Casino du Lac-Leamy. In August
column2: the Casino hosts an international fireworks competition which opposes four different countries with the winner being awarded a Prix Zeus prize for the best overall show (based on several criteria) and can return in the following year. At the beginning of September
column3: on Labour Day weekend
column4: Gatineau hosts an annual hot air balloon festival which fills the skies with colourful gas-fired passenger balloons.

column1: There are many parks. Some of them are well gardened playgrounds or resting spaces while others
column2: like Lac Beauchamp Park
column3: are relatively wild green areas which often merge with the woods and fields of the surrounding municipalities. Streams of all sizes run through these natural expanses. Most of the city is on level ground but the Northern and Eastern parts lie on the beginnings of the foothills of the massive Canadian Shield
column4: or Laurentian Mountains. These are the "Gatineau Hills"
column5: and are visible in the background of the companion picture. One of Gatineau's urban parks
column7: is used by the National Capital Commission during the popular festival

column1: Nightlife within the city of Gatineau is mostly centered in the "Vieux-Hull" sector behind the Federal office complexes of downtown. The area features many bars and restaurants within a stone's throw from Ottawa. It is a popular spot for young Ontarians as the legal drinking age in Quebec is 18 (as opposed to Ontario's 19).
The education system in Quebec is different from other systems in Canada. Between high school
column2: which ends at grade 11
column3: and university
column4: students must go through an additional school called CEGEP
column5: or Collège d'enseignement général et professionnel. CEGEPs offer both pre-university (2-years) and technical (3-years) programs.

column2: within its Hull neighborhood
column3: houses the main campus of the Université du Québec en Outaouais (UQO)
column4: part of the Université du Québec network. The UQO counts over 5
column5: 500 students
column6: mostly within its multiple social science programs. It is world-renowned for its cyber-psychology laboratory. Faced with a limited number of domains of study
column7: many Quebec students attend other universities
column8: either in Ottawa or Montreal. Every year
column9: the UQO hosts the Bar of Quebec course for certification of new lawyers.

column1: Gatineau is also the home of two CEGEPs
column2: including the francophone Cégep de l'Outaouais and the anglophone Heritage College.

column1: The main French-language school boards in Gatineau are the Commission scolaire des Portages-de-l'Outaouais
column2: the Commission scolaire au Coeur-des-Vallées
column3: and the Commission scolaire des Draveurs. There are also three private high schools : the all-girl Collège Saint-Joseph
column4: the Collège Saint-Alexandre
column5: and École secondaire Nouvelles-Frontières. Elementary and secondary education in English is under the supervision of the Western Quebec School Board.

column2: the National Autonomous University of Mexico (UNAM) has a campus in Gatineau.
McGill University announced the construction of a new campus for its Faculty of Medicine in the Outaouais region
column3: which will run the undergraduate medical education program in French and allow students to complete their undergraduate medical training entirely in the Outaouais. Official communication with politicians has been ongoing since 2016. The new facility will be erected above the emergency room at the Gatineau Hospital
column4: part of the Centre intégré de santé et de services sociaux de l'Outaouais
column5: in addition to new offices for the associated Family Medicine Unit for residency training. Although the preparatory year for students entering the undergraduate medical education program from CEGEP was initially planned to be offered solely at the McGill downtown campus in Montreal
column6: collaboration with the Université du Québec en Outaouais finally made it possible to offer the program entirely in Gatineau.

column1: The Gatineau-Ottawa Executive Airport is Gatineau's municipal airport
column2: capable of handling small jets. There are Canada customs facilities for aircraft coming from outside Canada
column3: a car rental counter and a restaurant. The airport has a few regularly scheduled flights to points within Quebec
column4: but most residents of Gatineau use the nearby Ottawa Macdonald–Cartier International Airport or travel to Montréal–Pierre Elliott Trudeau International Airport in Montreal.

column1: Ottawa and Gatineau have two distinct bus-based public transit systems with different fare structures
column2: OC Transpo and the Société de transport de l'Outaouais. Tickets are not interchangeable between the two
column3: however passes and transfers from one system to the other do not require payment of a surcharge on any routes. There is a proposed LRT system that would connect Gatineau to Bayview and Rideau Centre Stations in Ottawa.Many Gatineau highways and major arteries feed directly into the bridges crossing over to Ottawa
column4: but once there the roads lead into the dense downtown grid or into residential areas
column5: with no direct connection to The Queensway. This difficulty is further magnified by the lack of a major highway on the Quebec side of the Ottawa River connecting Gatineau to Montreal
column6: the metropolis of the province; most travellers from Gatineau to Montreal first cross over to Ottawa
column7: and use Ontario highways to access Montreal. However
column8: it is expected that since Autoroute 50 has been completed
column9: the new link between Gatineau and the Laurentides popular tourist area may serve as part of a Montreal by-pass by the north shore for Outaouais residents.

column1: The Gatineau Municipal Council (French: Le conseil municipal de Gatineau) is the city's main governing body. It is composed of 17 city councillors and a mayor.
The city serves as the seat of the judicial district of Gatineau
column2: which encompasses the entirety of the city of Gatineau as well as several outerlying municipalities such as Chelsea
column3: Cantley and Pontiac. The superior court serving the Outaouais region is located in Gatineau across from City Hall on the corner of Laurier and Hôtel-de-Ville. Most of the law firms that represent local businesses throughout the region are also based in Gatineau.

column2: the Service de police de la Ville de Gatineau (SPVG) provides day-to-day policing for the city
column3: in collaboration with other agencies such as the Sûreté du Québec and the Royal Canadian Mounted Police assisting as necessary. They are also responsible for patrolling sections of the highways located within the city limits
column4: including Autoroute 50 and Autoroute 5. The SPVG is equipped with a CID unit
column5: marine unit
column9: or GI). Patrol officers are armed with Smith & Wesson M&P .40 calibre pistols.  The SPVG uses the same vehicles as similar police forces throughout North America.

column1: Gatineau is the city of licence for several television and radio stations serving the National Capital Region
column2: which is a single media market. Many of the Ottawa-Gatineau region's TV and FM broadcast stations transmit from Camp Fortune just north of Gatineau. All of the stations licensed directly to Gatineau broadcast in French.

column1: Weekly newspapers published in Gatineau include Le Bulletin d'Aylmer (bilingual) and The West Quebec Post. Although Gatineau does not have its own daily newspaper
column2: it is served by daily newspapers published in Ottawa
column3: including the French Le Droit and the English Ottawa Citizen and Ottawa Sun.

column1: The Canadian Radio-television and Telecommunications Commission
column2: the Canadian regulatory agency for broadcasting

According to the 2011 census the city of Gatineau had a population of 265
column2: 349. This was an increase of 9.6% compared to 2006. Most of the population live in the urban cores of Aylmer
column3: Hull and the former Gatineau. Buckingham and Masson-Angers are more rural communities. Gatineau is the fourth largest city in Quebec after Montreal
column4: Quebec City
